description: Accounting is the language of business. It provides a framework for analyzing financial transactions and communicating economic information to investors, creditors, and other interested parties. The Bachelor of Science in Accounting program at Stony Brook University is designed to equip students with a strong foundation in accounting principles, financial reporting, auditing, taxation, and business law. Graduates are prepared for positions in public accounting, corporate accounting, government, and not-for-profit organizations. The program provides a foundation for students pursuing professional certification, such as the CPA or CMA.

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) program in Africana Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the experiences of African peoples and their descendants throughout the world. Students examine the history, culture, politics, economics, and social structures of African, African American, and Caribbean communities. The program emphasizes critical thinking, research skills, and an appreciation for diverse perspectives. Graduates are prepared for a variety of careers in fields such as education, public service, social justice, law, business, and international affairs, or for further graduate study.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies

description: Anthropology is a comparative and holistic discipline that explores humanity in all its breadth and depth. The program covers the four major fields of Anthropology (Cultural Anthropology, Archaeology, Biological Anthropology, and Linguistics) and offers students a variety of opportunities for fieldwork, laboratory research, and museum studies both at Stony Brook and abroad. Courses focus on human evolution, primate behavior, human variation, cultural diversity, social inequality, development, forensics, archaeology, language and cognition. The diverse interests of the faculty provide students with a broad and theoretically sophisticated understanding of the human condition.

The undergraduate program in Applied Mathematics and Statistics (AMS) provides students with a strong mathematical, statistical, and computational background that prepares them for careers in industry or government and for graduate study in applied mathematics, statistics, and other quantitative fields.
The program provides a solid foundation in calculus, linear algebra, discrete mathematics, and differential equations. It also provides a strong background in probability, statistical inference, and computational methods. A variety of elective courses in subjects such as operations research, mathematical finance, actuarial science, and mathematical biology, gives students the opportunity to learn about important modern applications of applied mathematics and statistics.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Applied Mathematics & Statistics

description: Art history provides a broad humanistic foundation and critical framework for understanding the visual arts and culture. The curriculum develops students’ analytical, research, and writing skills, while fostering visual literacy and critical thinking. It covers a range of historical periods, geographical regions, and theoretical approaches to diverse media including painting, sculpture, architecture, and new media. Beyond its inherent value as a liberal art, the study of art history prepares students for careers in museums, galleries, auction houses, publishing, education, conservation, historic preservation, government, and other areas of the art world. It is also an excellent preparation for graduate study in art history, law, or related fields. Students are encouraged to pursue an internship to gain practical experience.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Art History & Criticism
Bachelor of Arts in Art, Studio

description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Asian & Asian American Studies enables students to achieve a greater understanding of Asian and Asian American history, societies, politics, economies, and cultures. The curriculum offers students a broad, interdisciplinary learning experience with courses from the humanities, social sciences, and fine arts. Students can engage in the study of a particular Asian country or region, or focus on a specific thematic area such as Asian diaspora studies, transnationalism, globalization, or gender studies. With guidance from the undergraduate program director, students may create their own specialized course of study to meet their individual academic and professional goals. This program is offered by the Department of Asian & Asian American Studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Asian & Asian American Studies

description: The Department of Physics and Astronomy offers an undergraduate major leading to the Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Astronomy/Planetary Sciences. This is a rigorous program for students interested in a career as a professional astronomer or planetary scientist, or for students who wish to pursue graduate work in astronomy, planetary science, or a related field. It is suitable for students seeking a strong preparation in basic science with emphasis on the quantitative analysis required for modern astronomy and planetary science. The program emphasizes both theoretical and observational aspects of modern astronomy and planetary science, drawing on the expertise of faculty in the Department of Physics and Astronomy. Students are encouraged to participate in undergraduate research with faculty members. A number of internship opportunities exist for students at institutions like the American Museum of Natural History, Brookhaven National Laboratory, and the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. In addition, the department maintains an astronomical observatory on campus, which includes a 14-inch telescope available for both class use and undergraduate research.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Astronomy/Planetary Sciences

description: The Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences (AOS) Program at Stony Brook University provides students with a solid foundation in the physical and chemical processes governing the Earth’s atmosphere and oceans. Our program offers rigorous training in quantitative analysis, modeling, and observational techniques essential for understanding and predicting weather, climate, and ocean dynamics. Students will develop a strong background in mathematics, physics, and chemistry, applying these principles to complex environmental challenges. With a focus on interdisciplinary approaches, our graduates are well-prepared for careers in meteorology, oceanography, climate science, environmental consulting, and graduate studies.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Atmospheric and Oceanic Sciences

description: The Department of Biochemistry and Cell Biology provides an excellent environment for students interested in biochemical and molecular biological research. The Bachelor of Science program in Biochemistry prepares students for graduate work in biochemistry and related fields as well as careers in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical industries. Many of our graduates pursue careers in the health sciences including medicine, dentistry, and veterinary medicine. Students in the program develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills necessary for a career in science and medicine.

The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Biology is a liberal arts program designed for students interested in a broad education in biology with maximum flexibility in course selection. The BA degree does not include any specific area of specialization, and can be combined with other majors, minors, and pre-professional programs (e.g., Pre-Law, Pre-Med). Students completing the BA degree can continue their education in graduate programs, professional schools, or enter the workforce. The program learning outcomes for the BA in Biology are that students will be able to:
1. Demonstrate knowledge of major concepts, theoretical perspectives, empirical findings, and historical trends in biology.
2. Formulate and evaluate biological research questions, and design and execute experiments to address them.
3. Understand and apply scientific methods, including observation, experimentation, and quantitative analysis, to solve biological problems.
4. Effectively communicate scientific information in both written and oral formats.
5. Apply ethical principles to biological research and practice.

The B.S. program in Biology is designed for students interested in a broad training in biology and for students who intend to pursue careers in research, teaching, medicine, dentistry, or other health professions. This program provides students with a strong foundation in all areas of biology (molecular, cellular, organismal, and ecological/evolutionary biology), along with a strong background in chemistry, physics, and mathematics. Students also develop critical thinking and communication skills essential for success in diverse fields.

Biomedical engineering (BME) is a rapidly growing interdisciplinary field that combines engineering, biology, and medicine. Biomedical engineers work to advance human health by applying engineering principles and design concepts to medicine and biology. The BME curriculum combines a strong foundation in mathematics, physics, and chemistry with in-depth study of engineering and biological sciences and provides the necessary background for students to succeed in this field. Technical electives allow students to specialize in areas such as biomechanics, bioinstrumentation, biomaterials, and medical imaging. The program prepares students for graduate study in biomedical engineering and other related fields or for careers in the biomedical industry (e.g., medical devices, pharmaceutical, and biotechnology).
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Biomedical Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Business Management provides students with a strong foundation in business principles and practices, preparing them for a variety of careers in the private, public, and non-profit sectors. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, problem-solving, and ethical decision-making, equipping students with the skills necessary to succeed in a dynamic global business environment. Students gain a comprehensive understanding of core business functions, including accounting, finance, marketing, operations, and strategic management. The program also offers flexibility through electives, allowing students to explore areas of interest or prepare for graduate studies. Through rigorous coursework and experiential learning opportunities, students develop leadership potential and the ability to contribute effectively to organizations. The Business Management program provides a comprehensive business education grounded in the liberal arts and sciences. It prepares students for a wide range of careers in business, government, and not-for-profit organizations. It is also an excellent preparation for graduate study in business, law, or other fields. Through rigorous coursework, students develop analytical and problem-solving skills, learn to communicate effectively, and gain an understanding of ethical and social responsibility in business. The curriculum covers key functional areas of business, including accounting, finance, marketing, operations management, and strategic management. Students are encouraged to participate in internships, study abroad programs, and student organizations to gain practical experience and network with professionals.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Business Management

description: The undergraduate Chemical and Molecular Engineering (CME) program has been designed to provide students with a strong foundation in chemical engineering principles, as well as the advanced concepts of molecular engineering that are at the forefront of modern chemical technology. The curriculum encompasses a broad range of topics, including thermodynamics, transport phenomena, reaction kinetics, and process design, while also integrating molecular-level understanding of materials and processes. Students learn to apply engineering principles to design, analyze, and optimize systems involving chemical, physical, and biological transformations, preparing them for careers in diverse industries such as energy, pharmaceuticals, materials, and environmental management, or for further graduate studies.
Accreditation status: The Undergraduate Chemical and Molecular Engineering program is accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, https://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Chemical & Molecular Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Chemistry is designed to provide students with a strong background in chemistry, along with the flexibility to combine their studies with other academic interests or pre-professional programs. This program is suitable for students interested in careers that benefit from a chemical foundation, such as teaching, technical sales, environmental science, patent law, science writing, or various health professions. It also provides a solid preparation for graduate studies in chemistry or related fields, especially when supplemented with additional advanced coursework. Students completing the B.A. program will be prepared to critically analyze chemical problems, understand fundamental chemical principles, and apply laboratory techniques effectively.

The undergraduate program in Chemistry has as its goal the education of students in the fundamental principles of chemistry and biochemistry and the development of their ability to understand and to apply these principles to current problems in science and technology. This goal is accomplished through a balanced curriculum of lecture and laboratory courses that leads to a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Chemistry, a BS degree in Biochemistry, or a BA degree in Chemistry.
The department also offers a Minor in Chemistry. Students may participate in research and may earn academic credit for such work, including independent work with faculty.
The BS degree in Chemistry has three areas of study: Standard, Environmental Chemistry, and Chemical Physics. The BS in Chemistry with a Chemical Physics specialization is administered by the Department of Chemistry in cooperation with the Department of Physics and Astronomy. The BS in Biochemistry is described under Biochemistry, and the BA in Chemistry is described under Chemistry, B.A.

The Civil Engineering program provides students with a strong background in the scientific and mathematical principles underlying civil engineering, while developing in them an ability to integrate these principles into the design and analysis of civil engineering systems. It emphasizes fundamental concepts and their application to a variety of areas of civil engineering practice including: structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, transportation engineering, environmental engineering, and water resources engineering. The program prepares students for careers in the various specialties of civil engineering and for graduate study. The program curriculum is designed to satisfy the requirements for accreditation by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Accreditation status: Designed to satisfy the requirements for accreditation by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Civil Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Climate Science provides a comprehensive understanding of the Earth’s climate system, its variability, and human impacts on climate. The curriculum emphasizes quantitative skills and hands-on experience in analyzing and interpreting climate data and models. Students learn about the fundamental physical and chemical processes that govern the atmosphere, oceans, and land surface, as well as the interactions among these components. The program prepares students for graduate studies in climate science or related fields, as well as for careers in government agencies, environmental consulting firms, and non-profit organizations focused on climate change research, mitigation, and adaptation.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Climate Science

description:
Clinical Laboratory Scientists (CLS), sometimes called medical technologists or medical laboratory scientists, are an integral part of the healthcare team. Working in hospital, public health, and private clinical laboratories, these professionals perform and analyze a wide variety of laboratory tests used in the detection, diagnosis, and treatment of disease and in the maintenance of health.
The Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Sciences program prepares students to become highly skilled Clinical Laboratory Scientists, who are proficient in all areas of the clinical laboratory, including clinical chemistry, hematology, immunology, immunohematology (blood bank), and microbiology. Graduates are eligible to take national certification examinations and New York State licensure examinations to qualify them for employment.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the National Accrediting Agency for Clinical Laboratory Sciences (NAACLS), 5600 N. River Rd, Suite 720 Rosemont IL 60018-5119, (773) 714-8880.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Clinical Laboratory Sciences

description: The B.S. in Coastal Environmental Studies (CES) is a multi-disciplinary major intended for students interested in a scientific understanding of coastal environments and the impacts of human activities on them. Students must declare one of four specializations: Conservation and Restoration, Human Dimensions of Coastal Environments, Coastal Water and Ecosystem Health, or Coastal Geology and Geophysics. Located on the North Shore of Long Island, Stony Brook University offers an ideal location for the study of coastal environments. Access to Long Island Sound, the Atlantic Ocean, and many bays, estuaries, and wetlands, combined with dedicated research vessels and state-of-the-art facilities, provide many opportunities for students to participate in hands-on field and lab research. The CES major is a joint program between the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences (SoMAS) and the College of Arts and Sciences (CAS). Its multi-disciplinary nature makes it an excellent choice for students interested in graduate school or careers in environmental research, policy, and management.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Coastal Environmental Studies

description: The Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) program in Communication provides students with a broad knowledge of human communication processes. Students develop an understanding of communication across a variety of contexts, including interpersonal, small group, organizational, rhetorical, and intercultural settings, and acquire skills that allow them to analyze, evaluate, and produce effective and ethical communication. The program provides the foundations for understanding the production, content, and effects of communication as well as communication in new media. It is designed to develop students’ abilities to critically assess different perspectives and theories, engage in ethical reasoning, conduct and interpret communication research, and apply acquired knowledge to solve problems in real-world settings. Communication majors are prepared for a range of professional careers in fields such as business, education, government, healthcare, law, non-profit management, and public service, or for advanced graduate study.

The Bachelor of Engineering (B.E.) in Computer Engineering program provides students with a strong foundation in digital hardware design, computer architecture, computer networks, and embedded systems, with an emphasis on both hardware and software aspects of computer systems. Graduates of the program are well-prepared for careers in various industries, including software development, hardware design, embedded systems, and cybersecurity, as well as for graduate studies in computer engineering or related fields.
Accreditation status: Both the Electrical Engineering and Computer Engineering undergraduate programs at Stony Brook University are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET, www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Engineering in Computer Engineering

description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) program in Computer Science is accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org. The BS program prepares students for careers in computer science or for graduate study. The program requires a total of 120 credits. Requirements for the BS in Computer Science include a set of core courses, a statistics requirement, upper-division computer science courses, technical electives, and a written communication course. In addition to the Computer Science major requirements, students must also satisfy the University’s general education requirements (SBC) and earn at least 120 credits total.
Accreditation status: Accredited by the Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET, http://www.abet.org.
Program name: Bachelor of Science in Computer Science

description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts in Creative Writing provides students with an intensive undergraduate course of study in the writing of fiction, poetry, and screenwriting. It is designed to prepare students for careers in writing, publishing, journalism, teaching, and for graduate study in creative writing. The program offers workshops at the beginning and advanced level, as well as courses in literary theory, history, and practice. The curriculum requires students to take courses in a variety of literary forms and to complete a significant amount of coursework in literature. The BFA in Creative Writing requires 60 credits in creative writing and literature courses, with a minimum of 36 credits in creative writing workshops. Students must take courses in fiction, poetry, and screenwriting, and must complete an advanced workshop in at least two genres. The program culminates in a senior thesis, a substantial work of creative writing in the student’s chosen genre, completed under the guidance of a faculty mentor. Students are encouraged to participate in literary internships and to take advantage of the many literary events and readings offered through the English Department and the College of Arts and Sciences.
Program name: Bachelor of Fine Arts in Creative Writing
Bachelor of Science in Data Science

description: The Earth and Space Sciences (ESS) program at Stony Brook University seeks to provide students with a broad and deep understanding of Earth and planetary systems across time and space, including the processes that govern the solid Earth, its oceans and atmosphere, and their interactions with living systems, as well as the solar system and universe beyond. The curriculum is designed to foster critical thinking, problem-solving skills, and scientific literacy, preparing students for diverse careers and/or advanced studies in the geosciences, environmental sciences, space sciences, and related fields, and to be engaged citizens with a scientifically informed perspective on pressing societal issues related to Earth and space. Graduates of the Earth and Space Sciences program will be able to: Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of Earth's major systems and their interactions (geosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere, biosphere) and how they have evolved over geological time. Apply foundational principles of physics, chemistry, biology, and mathematics to analyze and solve problems in Earth and space sciences. Interpret and critically evaluate scientific data, including geological, geophysical, geochemical, and remote sensing data, to draw evidence-based conclusions. Utilize modern scientific instrumentation, field techniques, and computational tools relevant to Earth and space sciences. Communicate scientific information effectively, both orally and in writing, to diverse audiences. Understand the societal relevance of Earth and space sciences, including issues related to natural resources, hazards, climate change, and environmental sustainability.
Program name: Bachelor of Arts in Earth & Space Sciences

description: The Minor in Accounting provides students with an overview of the fundamentals of accounting, preparing them for potential careers in the field or for further study.

The Africana Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the experiences of African peoples throughout the world. Drawing on fields such as history, literature, sociology, political science, and anthropology, the minor examines the historical, cultural, economic, and political forces that have shaped the lives of people of African descent. Students completing the minor will develop critical thinking skills, a global perspective, and a nuanced understanding of race, culture, and power.

Anthropology is the comparative study of humanity, with the ultimate goal of understanding our diversity in the past and present. The discipline is traditionally divided into four subdisciplines: archaeological anthropology (the study of past societies through their material remains), biological anthropology (the study of human evolution and variation), linguistic anthropology (the study of the relationship between language and culture), and sociocultural anthropology (the study of living human societies and cultures). Anthropology offers a broad liberal arts education that focuses on critical thinking, fieldwork skills, and cross-cultural understanding. Anthropological training prepares students for a wide range of careers, including archaeology, museum work, international business, law, medicine, public health, education, cultural resource management, forensics, governmental and non-governmental organizations, and international development.

This minor is designed for students who desire to enhance their quantitative skills to complement their major field of study, whether it is in the sciences, engineering, business, or the social sciences. The program emphasizes applied aspects of mathematics and statistics, covering topics such as probability, statistical inference, data analysis, and mathematical modeling, equipping students with a robust foundation for careers in diverse fields that increasingly rely on data-driven decision-making.
Program name: Minor in Applied Mathematics and Statistics

description: Art History is a humanistic discipline that studies the visual arts (architecture, painting, sculpture, new media, etc.) across various cultures and historical periods. It is concerned with the creation, functions, and interpretation of images and objects within specific social, political, and economic contexts. As a field, Art History is fundamentally interdisciplinary, drawing on a wide range of methodologies and theoretical perspectives, including aesthetics, semiotics, psychoanalysis, feminism, postcolonialism, and queer theory. The Art History minor enables students to develop their critical thinking skills through the analysis of different forms of visual expression while expanding their knowledge of cultural history. The minor is a useful complement to a wide range of majors in the humanities (e.g., English, History, Philosophy, Languages, Literatures, and Cultures), social sciences (e.g., Sociology, Political Science, Economics), and sciences (e.g., Biology, Chemistry, Computer Science). Art History fosters visual literacy, critical reasoning, and analytical skills that are highly valued in diverse professional fields, including education, law, medicine, technology, and publishing.

The Minor in Art provides students with the opportunity to pursue an interest in visual art within the context of a liberal arts education. It also enables students to develop a body of work in a particular area of studio art. The minor offers a range of studio art courses in painting, drawing, sculpture, photography, digital art, printmaking, and ceramics.

Asian American Studies is an interdisciplinary program that explores the history, culture, and contemporary experiences of Asian Americans. The minor provides students with a critical understanding of race, ethnicity, immigration, and globalization through the lens of Asian American experiences. Students will develop analytical skills applicable to a wide range of fields, including education, social work, law, public policy, and community organizing. The minor is designed for students interested in a global perspective on American society and its diverse populations.

The Minor in Asian and Asian American Studies offers students an opportunity to learn about the histories, cultures, and experiences of Asians and Asian Americans. The minor allows students to pursue their interest in Asia and its diaspora through a range of courses offered across different departments and programs in the College of Arts and Sciences. The minor is interdisciplinary and introduces students to different theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of Asia and Asian America. The minor is a valuable credential for students considering graduate study in fields such as Ethnic Studies and Asian Studies as well as for those pursuing careers in education, public policy, government, and non-profit sectors where understanding the complexities of Asian and Asian American communities is increasingly important.
Program name: Minor in Asian and Asian American Studies

description: The Minor in Asian Thought provides students with an opportunity to gain familiarity with the intellectual and aesthetic traditions of the major civilizations of Asia. Courses emphasize texts from the humanities and social sciences. The program encourages students to investigate a variety of approaches to the study of Asian thought. The minor provides a strong interdisciplinary foundation for careers in government, international business, and journalism, and for further study in law, business, and graduate school in relevant fields.

The minor in astronomy is designed for students who wish to gain a deeper understanding of astronomy than is offered by introductory general education courses. The minor provides a solid background for students interested in a wide range of career fields, from science journalism to education, and prepares students for more advanced study in astronomy. Students will learn about topics such as planetary science, stars, galaxies, and cosmology. Students will also develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills, and gain experience with scientific methods.

The minor in Bioengineering is for engineering students interested in a career in biomedical engineering, medicine, medical devices, or the pharmaceutical industry. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credits. At least 9 credits must be 300-level or higher. Students are required to take BME 200, BME 201, BME 203, and three additional courses in BME at the 300 level or higher. No course for the minor can be taken on a pass/fail basis. All courses must have a grade of C or higher. Note: Students in the Biomedical Engineering major cannot declare the Minor in Bioengineering. For more information on the minor, please visit the Department of Biomedical Engineering webpage.

A minor in Biology is designed to provide students with a solid foundation in the fundamental principles of biology. It is suitable for students who wish to supplement their major with a strong background in life sciences. The curriculum provides flexibility to allow students to tailor their course selection to their interests within biology while ensuring a broad exposure to the field.

The minor in Black Heritage Studies (BLH) allows students to critically engage with the study of African American, African, and Afro-diasporic peoples and their cultures, histories, politics, and social experiences. Students electing the minor will develop an interdisciplinary perspective on Black heritage through a wide variety of courses in the humanities and social sciences. The minor helps students develop critical thinking skills, historical awareness, and an understanding of the complex issues related to race, identity, and social justice, preparing them for diverse career paths and informed civic engagement. The program requires 21 credits, including a core course and a distribution of courses across different themes.

The Minor in Chemistry offers students in other majors the opportunity to obtain a working knowledge of chemistry sufficient to understand basic chemical phenomena and its relevance to their lives. It also serves as preparation for graduate work in other fields such as biology, materials science or environmental science, for which a grounding in chemistry is particularly valuable. The minor requires a minimum of 21 credits. Students completing a major in chemistry are not eligible for the minor.

The Minor in China Studies provides students with an opportunity to gain an interdisciplinary understanding of China and Chinese culture, society, history, language, and politics. Students completing the minor will have an understanding of the diversity and dynamism of Chinese civilization and its relationship to the modern world.

A minor in Classics provides students with the opportunity to achieve familiarity with the classical languages and civilization of ancient Greece and Rome. This minor provides a foundation in classical studies and an introduction to the methodologies employed in the study of classical civilization. The minor will be of value to students majoring in a wide variety of subjects, including humanities, social sciences, and the natural sciences. Students interested in the minor should consult the Undergraduate Director of the Department of Classics. All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade. Completion of the minor requires 21 credits. Students must complete a minimum of 9 credits in courses at or above the 300-level. No more than 6 transfer credits may be applied to the minor.

The Minor in Climate Solutions is designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of Earth's climate system, the impacts of climate change, and various mitigation and adaptation strategies. It is an interdisciplinary minor drawing on courses from across the University and is suitable for any major. The minor will help students develop a comprehensive understanding of the scientific, social, economic, and policy dimensions of climate change. Students will gain analytical and critical thinking skills to evaluate climate-related challenges and propose solutions, preparing them for careers in sustainability, environmental policy, research, and other related fields, or for further graduate study.

Coastal environments are among the most dynamic and productive ecosystems on Earth, but they are also among the most threatened by human impacts. This interdepartmental Minor is designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the scientific, social, economic, and policy issues relevant to the sustainable management and conservation of coastal environments. It is a perfect complement to a wide range of majors including marine sciences, environmental studies, biology, geology, political science, economics, and business. The Minor is open to all students, and provides both a strong foundation for students interested in graduate studies or careers in coastal environmental management, and a valuable addition to the education of students interested in environmental issues.

Communication is a broad field, encompassing a wide array of theoretical approaches and applied practices. The field is typically defined by its focus on the processes, messages, contexts, and effects of human communication. The Communication minor will give students an interdisciplinary perspective on the study of communication and allow them to gain a theoretical and analytical foundation, including an understanding of current topics and debates. Upon completion of the Communication minor, students will be able to: 1. Understand and apply fundamental theories, concepts, and approaches in the study of communication. 2. Identify and describe current topics and debates in the field of communication. 3. Apply communication theories and concepts to analyze and address specific communication issues, problems, and situations. 4. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding of relevant ethical issues in communication. 5. Critically evaluate and synthesize information from a variety of sources related to communication.

The Minor in Communication and Innovation (CMI) is an interdisciplinary program designed to equip students with critical skills and perspectives for understanding, engaging with, and shaping communication in a rapidly evolving technological landscape. This minor emphasizes the interplay between communication theory, digital technologies, and societal impact. Students will explore how new media and innovative tools transform human interaction, public discourse, and organizational practices. Through a blend of theoretical coursework and practical application, students will develop competencies in areas such as digital storytelling, media analytics, strategic communication, and ethical considerations in technological innovation. The CMI minor aims to prepare students for diverse career paths in fields like digital marketing, media production, public relations, technology policy, and user experience design, by fostering adaptability, critical thinking, and creativity essential for navigating the complexities of the 21st-century communication environment.

The Computer Science Minor provides a basic understanding of computer science concepts, programming, and problem-solving techniques. It is designed for students in other disciplines who wish to acquire a foundation in computer science to complement their major fields of study. The minor requires a minimum of 20 credits, including specific courses in programming, data structures, and computer organization, along with elective credits in computer science. This minor enhances a student's analytical and technical skills, making them more competitive in a technology-driven world.

The Minor in Creative Writing consists of 21 credits beyond the introductory course. All courses for the minor must be taken for a letter grade and passed with a grade of C or higher. A maximum of 6 credits may be transferred from another institution. No more than 6 credits may be double counted with a student's major, and no more than 3 credits may be double counted with another minor.

Students wishing to pursue the Minor in Creative Writing should consult the undergraduate director of Creative Writing.

Completion of the minor requires a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.50 in the courses applied to the minor.

The minor in Digital Arts provides students with an opportunity to gain an understanding of the concepts and techniques for creating art using digital media. Students who complete the minor will have fundamental skills in one or more digital arts areas (e.g., imaging, animation, web, games, interactive art, 3D modeling, digital fabrication).

The minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact provides students with the fundamental understanding of how ecosystems function and how human activities affect the sustainability of ecosystems and the services they provide. The minor focuses on critical analysis of environmental issues and emphasizes the interdisciplinary and multidisciplinary nature of environmental problem solving. The courses in the minor cover topics related to population dynamics, ecological communities, energy flow, biogeochemical cycles, human demography, global climate change, conservation biology, ecosystem restoration, environmental policy, and environmental justice. This minor can complement a wide range of majors including those in the natural sciences, social sciences, engineering, and humanities. It is designed for students who are interested in pursuing careers related to environmental sustainability, conservation, policy, or education.
Program name: Minor in Ecosystems and Human Impact

description: The minor in Electrical Engineering is intended for students who wish to gain a basic understanding of electrical engineering principles. It requires 21 credits of coursework focusing on the fundamental concepts of electrical circuits, electronics, and digital systems. Students will learn how to analyze and design simple electrical and electronic circuits, understand the operation of basic digital systems, and gain hands-on experience through laboratory work. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in careers or graduate studies in fields that integrate electrical engineering concepts.

The minor in English allows students to focus on areas of interest to them within the discipline while providing them with the valuable analytical, critical reading, and communication skills for which the study of literature is especially renowned. Students choose from a range of courses in literary study, critical theory, and writing. Courses in the English major are open to English minors; many count toward the minor requirements.

This minor introduces students to the challenges of achieving environmental sustainability within diverse geographic and cultural settings, and to the analytical and practical tools that can be used to meet these challenges. The minor is offered jointly by the Sustainability Studies Program, the Department of Urban and Community Studies, and the Department of Ecology and Evolution. The Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of sustainable practices and environmental issues. Students will learn about environmental planning, policy-making, and design principles, providing them with a foundation to address complex environmental problems. This minor is suitable for students interested in careers in environmental management, urban planning, policy analysis, and related fields.
Program name: Minor in Environmental Design, Policy, and Planning

description: The Minor in Environmental Engineering is designed to provide students with a fundamental background in environmental engineering principles related to water resources, air pollution, solid/hazardous waste, and environmental site assessment and remediation. The minor provides students with the fundamentals of environmental engineering analysis and design required to pursue a career or graduate studies in environmental engineering or environmental science. This minor is open to all students.

Environmental Humanities is an interdisciplinary field that brings the insights of the humanities (philosophy, history, literature, cultural studies, ethics, media studies, religious studies, and the arts) to bear on the problems and questions posed by environmental change. It offers students the opportunity to explore the human dimensions of environmental issues such as climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and resource depletion, providing a crucial complement to scientific and technical approaches. The Minor will introduce students to the diverse methodologies and approaches of the Environmental Humanities and develop their capacities for critical inquiry, analytical thinking, and ethical engagement with the challenges of the Anthropocene. Students will learn to analyze environmental issues through various lenses, including historical context, cultural representation, ethical frameworks, and philosophical inquiry, thereby fostering a deeper understanding of the complex interplay between human societies and the natural world.

The minor in Environmental Studies is an interdisciplinary minor designed to provide students with the opportunity to pursue an interest in environmental issues as a complement to their major program of study. The minor requires a minimum of 21 credits selected from an approved list of courses offered by departments across the University. Students must complete a minimum of three credits from at least three different departments. For more information regarding course selection for the Environmental Studies minor, students should contact the faculty director or the undergraduate program director in the School of Marine and Atmospheric Sciences.

The Minor in Ethnomusicology provides students with an introduction to the interdisciplinary study of world musics and associated cultures. It emphasizes the critical relationship between music, sound, and the human experience, examining diverse musical traditions within their cultural and social contexts. Students will explore theoretical frameworks and methodologies used in ethnomusicology, including fieldwork, ethnographic research, and sound studies. Through courses in various world musical traditions (e.g., African, Asian, Latin American, Middle Eastern), students will develop a broad understanding of global musical diversity and its significance. The minor encourages critical listening skills, cultural sensitivity, and an appreciation for the role of music in shaping identity, community, and social change. It complements studies in music, anthropology, sociology, cultural studies, and global affairs, providing valuable perspectives for students interested in careers in arts, education, international relations, and cultural heritage.

The Minor in Film and Screen Studies is an interdepartmental minor with offerings in the departments of Cultural Analysis and Theory (College of Arts and Sciences) and English (College of Arts and Sciences). It introduces students to film and television as artistic, cultural, and industrial forms, as well as to their historical development and theoretical approaches. Courses in the minor focus on the aesthetic, social, and cultural analysis of film and screen media, and they are typically drawn from the fields of Film Studies, Media Studies, Literary and Cultural Studies, and Art History. The minor is suitable for students pursuing a wide range of majors in the humanities, social sciences, and arts, and it can enrich students’ understanding of the pervasive influence of screen media on contemporary culture.
Program name: Minor in Film and Screen Studies

description: The Minor in Filmmaking is designed for students who want to develop their knowledge and skills in film and media production. Students will learn the fundamentals of screenwriting, directing, producing, cinematography, editing, and sound design across a variety of genres and formats, including narrative, documentary, and experimental film. The program emphasizes hands-on experience and critical thinking about film as an art form and a medium of communication.

The minor in Finance allows students who are not majoring in Business Management to gain an understanding of the concepts, theories, institutions, and analytical tools associated with financial markets, instruments, and decisions. The minor is appropriate for students interested in careers in finance, and for those who wish to enhance their business knowledge to complement other career interests. Students completing the minor will have a solid foundation in the principles of financial management, investments, and financial markets.

The minor in French will afford students the opportunity to complement their major studies with a deeper insight into French and Francophone language, literature and cultures, providing them with a strong basis in French that can be applied to a variety of areas of study including careers in education, communication, business, law and global studies.

A minor in Geology provides students with an understanding of Earth processes including volcanism, earthquakes, mountain building, the rock cycle, evolution of life, global change, and natural resources. These studies are critical for careers in environmental studies, natural resources, engineering, earth science teaching, and basic research. It is possible to earn a minor in Geology by completing 20 credits in Geosciences as outlined below. Students must fulfill University General Education requirements within their major.

The Geospatial Science minor is an interdepartmental minor in the College of Arts and Sciences designed to provide students with foundational knowledge of spatial information science and spatial data analysis. This minor provides students with skills in Geographic Information Systems (GIS), remote sensing, cartography, and spatial statistics which are in high demand in a wide range of fields including environmental science, urban planning, public health, business, and social sciences. The minor also prepares students for further graduate study in geospatial science.

The Minor in Globalization Studies and International Relations, administered by the Department of Political Science, is an interdisciplinary program designed for students seeking to understand the nature and scope of globalization in its political, economic, historical, and cultural dimensions. Students explore the connections between globalization and international relations and analyze the challenges and opportunities posed by an increasingly interconnected world. The program also examines the impact of globalization on various regions of the world, including the United States. Students gain an understanding of global challenges, such as sustainable development, human rights, global health, and international conflict, and develop critical thinking skills necessary to engage with complex global issues. The minor complements a wide range of majors in the social sciences, humanities, and fine arts.
Program name: Minor in Globalization Studies and International Relations

description: The Minor in Health, Medicine, and Society (HMS) offers students the opportunity to examine the social dimensions of health, illness, and healthcare systems. Using sociological perspectives, students learn to critically analyze health and healthcare issues that are increasingly relevant to our society and daily lives. This minor is designed for students interested in careers in healthcare, public health, medicine, social work, public policy, or research, as well as students seeking to broaden their understanding of health, illness, and society.
Program name: Minor in Health, Medicine, and Society

description: The Minor in Hellenic Studies provides students with the opportunity to explore the rich culture of Greece, ancient, Byzantine, and modern. It offers a structured introduction to the fields of Greek history, art, language, literature, philosophy, and religion through a variety of courses offered by several departments. The minor is suitable for students who wish to pursue their interest in Greek culture and complement their major field of study. It is also designed for students who want to prepare for graduate study in Hellenic Studies.

The History of Health, Science, and the Environment minor explores how different societies have understood and interacted with disease, bodies, nature, and the cosmos from ancient times to the present. The program is explicitly interdisciplinary, drawing on a range of fields including history, philosophy, sociology, anthropology, and journalism. Students will learn how to analyze the historical development of science, technology, and medicine; trace the shifting conceptions of health, illness, and the body; examine the evolving relationship between humans and the natural world; and consider the ethical, social, and political implications of scientific and technological change.
Program name: Minor in History of Health, Science, and the Environment

description: Industrial engineering is concerned with the design, improvement, and installation of integrated systems of people, materials, information, equipment, and energy. Industrial engineers apply specialized knowledge and skills in the mathematical, physical, and social sciences, together with the principles and methods of engineering analysis and design, to specify, predict, and evaluate the results to be obtained from such systems.

The Minor in Information Systems provides students with an understanding of how information systems are developed, deployed, and managed. Information systems are the backbone of modern organizations, and professionals with expertise in information systems are in high demand across all industries. This minor is open to all undergraduate students. The minor requires a total of 21 credits. Students must complete five required courses (15 credits) and two elective courses (6 credits). A minimum grade of C must be achieved in all courses used to fulfill the minor requirements. Completion of the minor will be noted on the student’s official transcript.

The minor in Italian American Studies provides an interdisciplinary approach to the study of the Italian American experience. It gives students the opportunity to examine the history, sociology, literature, and culture of Italian Americans. The minor provides a strong foundation for students interested in a variety of fields, including teaching, law, social work, journalism, and public service. It also prepares students for further academic work in Italian American Studies or related disciplines.

The Minor in Italian Studies, offered by the Department of Linguistics, consists of courses in Italian language, literature, and culture. The minor requires a minimum of 18 credits, of which at least 12 credits must be taken at Stony Brook University. Only courses in which the student has earned a grade of C or higher may be counted toward the minor. For more information, please contact the Department of Linguistics.

The Minor in Japanese Studies is intended to provide students with knowledge of Japanese language and culture, through a combination of language and culture/civilization courses. Students take five courses for a minimum of 18 credits. All students pursuing the minor must meet with the undergraduate advisor for Japanese to declare their interest in the minor. The minor must be completed with a minimum GPA of 2.0 in courses for the minor. Students should consult the Department of Asian and Asian American Studies website for additional information. Transfer students who wish to apply courses from other institutions toward the minor must consult with the undergraduate advisor. For information on a minor in Asian American Studies, see Asian and Asian American Studies. For information on the Major in Asian and Asian American Studies with a concentration in Japanese Studies, see Asian and Asian American Studies.

The Minor in Jazz Music provides students with an in-depth understanding of the foundations of jazz performance, history, and theory. Designed to complement majors in other disciplines, the minor enhances musical skills, cultural appreciation, and creative expression through a rigorous curriculum covering improvisation, ensemble playing, jazz history from its origins to contemporary forms, and theoretical frameworks unique to jazz. Students will develop proficiency in jazz performance and gain a comprehensive knowledge of the genre's rich cultural heritage.

The Minor in Journalism is a 21-credit program that gives students interested in journalism and related professions grounding in the practical and ethical principles of journalism. It offers training in basic news writing and reporting skills, as well as an understanding of the impact of journalism on society.
The minor is administered by the School of Communication and Journalism.
See "Courses" for a complete list of classes and descriptions.
The Minor in Journalism can be combined with any major except Journalism, and is open to any student with a cumulative grade point average of 2.50 or higher, including transfer students.
For more information, visit stonybrook.edu/journalism.
Declaration of the Minor: Students seeking to declare the minor should complete the online declaration form available on the School of Communication and Journalism website, along with any other requirements specific to the minor. Students interested in the minor should consult with the Undergraduate Program Director for advising.

The Minor in Judaic Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive background in the study of Jewish civilization and culture. The program aims to promote knowledge of Jewish history, religion, languages, literature, politics, and the arts, from antiquity to the present. The minor is suitable for students who wish to supplement their major with a substantial body of knowledge in Judaic studies. Students in the minor are encouraged to develop their interests in consultation with the department.

The minor in Korean Studies allows students to develop an understanding of Korean language, history, and culture and engage in a comparative study of East Asia. The minor is offered by the Department of Asian and Asian American Studies.
Students who complete the minor will be able to:
1. Demonstrate an intermediate proficiency in Korean language.
2. Demonstrate an understanding of Korean history and cultural traditions.
3. Compare and contrast Korean society and culture with other East Asian countries.
4. Interpret Korean cultural products within their historical and social contexts.

The Minor in Latin American and Caribbean Studies provides an interdisciplinary and transnational approach to the study of Latin America and the Caribbean. Drawing on courses from across the social sciences and humanities, students in the Minor will gain a broad understanding of the region’s histories, cultures, politics, and economies. Students will develop an understanding of the region as a complex and diverse area connected to global processes, including migration and globalization, while also exploring specific topics such as indigenous cultures, social movements, and environmental issues. The Minor will equip students with analytical and critical thinking skills to analyze the complexities of the region and its connections to the wider world. It is open to all students and complements a variety of majors.
Program name: Minor in Latin American and Caribbean Studies

description: The minor in Manufacturing Engineering provides students with an overview of the tools, techniques and strategies of modern manufacturing. The curriculum covers the materials, processes and systems of manufacturing. Topics such as conventional and advanced manufacturing processes, process planning and control, automation, and computer-integrated manufacturing are covered. Students completing the minor will have a strong foundation for careers in manufacturing and related areas such as product design, process engineering, and quality control.

The Marine Sciences minor provides an excellent opportunity for students to acquire a broad understanding of the scientific study of the oceans through courses in marine biology, chemistry, geology and physics. The minor can complement a wide variety of majors, especially those in the natural sciences, by providing students with an opportunity to integrate their primary field of study with the interdisciplinary field of marine sciences. The minor also provides students with a general introduction to the marine sciences, serving as a basis for further study in this field.

The Minor in Mass Communication allows students from any major to gain a basic understanding of the role of mass media in contemporary society and to acquire practical skills in the areas of writing, researching, and producing mass communication messages. The minor is suitable for students interested in careers in advertising, public relations, journalism, corporate and non-profit communications, and media production.

Materials Science is an interdisciplinary field that investigates the relationships between the structure, processing, properties, and performance of materials. This minor provides an introduction to the fundamental concepts of materials science and engineering. Students will gain an understanding of different classes of materials (metals, ceramics, polymers, composites), their atomic and microscopic structures, and how these structures influence properties such as mechanical strength, electrical conductivity, and optical behavior. The minor also covers basic material processing techniques and characterization methods. It is suitable for students in various engineering and science disciplines who wish to broaden their knowledge in this essential field. The minor prepares students for entry-level positions in materials-related industries or for further study in materials science and engineering.

The Minor in Mathematics is for students from other disciplines who desire a stronger background in mathematics than can be obtained from the introductory calculus sequence. The minor provides a background suitable for students whose major requires substantial mathematical skills or who wish to pursue graduate work in a mathematically oriented field. Courses taken for the minor may not be taken under the Pass/No Credit option.

The Minor in Mechanical Engineering is intended for non-ME majors who wish to demonstrate to prospective employers or graduate schools a proficiency in the fundamental principles of mechanical engineering. It provides an exposure to the various sub-disciplines within mechanical engineering, including mechanics, thermal fluids sciences, and design and manufacturing, and provides students with a solid foundation to pursue careers or further studies in these areas. Students completing the minor will have a better understanding of how devices and systems work.

This minor is designed for students who are interested in the languages, cultures, religions, politics, and history of the Middle East, broadly defined to include North Africa, Central Asia, and the Caucasus. Students who complete the minor will gain a basic understanding of the history and development of the region, its varied cultures and societies, and its growing importance in contemporary global affairs. A wide range of courses, drawn from several departments, will enable students to choose a course of study appropriate to their individual interests. Students may choose to focus on a particular subregion, such as North Africa, or a particular topic, such as the history of a specific religion. The minor can complement a wide variety of majors, including Anthropology, Art History, Asian and Asian American Studies, Comparative Literature, History, Linguistics, Political Science, Religious Studies, Sociology, and Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies.

The minor in music is designed to introduce students to the diverse field of music, including its history, theory, and cultural contexts. The minor complements a wide range of majors by fostering critical listening skills, creative expression, and an understanding of music's role in human experience. Students will engage with various musical traditions and develop foundational knowledge in music theory, analysis, and performance.

The Nanotechnology Studies (NTS) minor is an interdisciplinary program designed for students wishing to pursue careers or graduate studies in fields that integrate knowledge of science, engineering, and technology with an understanding of the societal impact and entrepreneurial aspects of nanotechnology. It is a STEM-designated minor open to all majors. The minor will provide students with a solid foundation in the fundamental science and engineering principles of nanotechnology and an appreciation for its broader implications.

The Minor in Native American and Indigenous Studies is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the histories, cultures, and contemporary experiences of Native American and Indigenous peoples. The minor draws on courses from various departments including Africana Studies, Anthropology, English, History, Political Science, and Sociology. Students will explore a range of topics, including Indigenous sovereignty, land rights, environmental justice, cultural preservation, and decolonization movements. The program encourages critical thinking about Indigenous issues from both historical and contemporary perspectives, fostering a nuanced understanding of Native American and Indigenous contributions to global societies.
Program name: Minor in Native American and Indigenous Studies

description: The Minor in Optics provides students with a fundamental education in optics and photonics. This program is suitable for students from a range of science and engineering majors who wish to demonstrate to future employers or graduate schools a proficiency in the field of optics. The minor requires completion of a total of 18 credits from the approved list of courses. The selection of courses is approved by the Program Director. Successful completion of the minor is recorded on the student's official transcript.

The minor in philosophy provides students with an opportunity to explore philosophical problems and ways of thinking. The minor is a useful complement to a wide variety of majors, helping students to develop analytical and interpretive skills that are valuable in any field. The requirements for the minor are structured to provide students with a solid foundation in the history of philosophy, while also allowing them to pursue their own interests in specific areas of philosophy.

The minor in Physics gives students an opportunity to obtain a broader science background and an introduction to Physics as a basic science. It provides the necessary foundation for students interested in graduate studies in areas such as Biophysics, Medical Physics, and Astronomy.

The Department of Political Science offers a minor in Political Science. The minor offers students the opportunity to learn about the nature of political power, the institutions through which it is exercised, the policies it yields, the processes through which it is formed, and the ideas and values that shape and challenge it, both in the United States and across the globe. By exposing students to the various aspects of political analysis, the minor is designed to help students acquire a richer understanding of current events, hone their analytical and critical thinking skills, and enhance their ability to express themselves clearly and effectively both orally and in writing. The minor may be combined with any major. Students interested in the minor should consult with the undergraduate director of the Department of Political Science for help in planning their course of study.

The Minor in Professional Writing provides instruction in how to communicate clearly and effectively in a variety of professional and public contexts. It is a valuable credential for students considering careers that require strong writing skills, such as business, law, medicine, journalism, public relations, technical writing, scientific writing, and publishing. The Minor develops critical thinking and research skills, as well as the ability to adapt writing to different purposes and audiences. Students will gain experience writing a variety of professional documents, including proposals, reports, letters, memos, web content, and other forms of professional discourse. It is an excellent complement to any major.

This minor is designed for students in any major who are interested in understanding the fundamental principles of real estate and insurance. This minor will provide students with the foundational knowledge and skills to pursue careers in real estate, insurance, or related fields. The minor combines courses from Business, Economics, and Sustainability Studies, offering a multidisciplinary perspective on the complex issues and challenges in these industries. Students will learn about property valuation, real estate development, risk management, types of insurance, and the economic and legal aspects of real estate and insurance markets. Upon completion of this minor, students will have a strong understanding of the real estate and insurance industries, enhancing their career prospects in various sectors.
Program name: Minor in Real Estate and Insurance

description: The minor in Religious Studies offers students an opportunity to explore the historical and cultural significance of religion as a human phenomenon. Religious beliefs, practices, and institutions have shaped civilizations and continue to play a crucial role in contemporary society. The minor takes an interdisciplinary approach to the study of religion, drawing upon methods and insights from history, philosophy, anthropology, sociology, literature, and art history. Students are introduced to a broad range of religious traditions from around the world and across different historical periods, including Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Buddhism, Hinduism, and indigenous religions. The program emphasizes critical thinking, analytical skills, and cultural understanding, preparing students to engage with diverse perspectives and complex global issues. The minor is suitable for students pursuing a wide variety of majors, as it complements studies in the humanities, social sciences, and even some natural sciences, providing a valuable foundation for careers in education, journalism, public service, law, and international relations.

The Russian Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of Russia’s history, culture, politics, and language. Students can choose to concentrate on a variety of fields and periods through courses in history, political science, sociology, anthropology, and literature. The minor requires a minimum of 21 credits.

The South Asian Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical perspective on the societies and cultures of South Asia and its diaspora. Students will have the opportunity to study South Asia from various disciplinary perspectives, including anthropology, art history, history, political science, religious studies, and sociology. South Asia, an area encompassing India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, and the Maldives, is home to a quarter of the world's population and is a growing force in the global economy and polity. Through a range of courses, students will explore topics such as colonialism, postcolonialism, nationalism, gender, religion, migration, and development within the region. The minor will enhance students' understanding of a region of increasing global importance and prepare them for careers in government, non-governmental organizations, journalism, business, and academia related to South Asia.

The minor in Spanish Language and Literature provides students with knowledge of the literature, culture, and civilization of the Spanish-speaking world while developing and refining their linguistic abilities. The minor is a valuable complement to a wide range of majors, including those in the humanities, social sciences, natural sciences, and business. It prepares students for a variety of professions in a globalized society.
Program name: Minor in Spanish Language and Literature

description: The Minor in Sustainability Studies focuses on the interdisciplinary character of sustainability studies and the interaction between human and natural systems. Through an interdisciplinary curriculum, students in the Minor in Sustainability Studies learn to combine perspectives from different disciplines to address the complex issues of sustainability. Students learn to recognize the inherent linkages between ecology, economics, ethics, equity, technology, policy, and other dimensions of sustainability. Students learn to consider a range of solutions to sustainability problems, and how to develop and implement these solutions.

The Minor in Television Writing at Stony Brook University prepares students to enter the rapidly growing field of television scriptwriting. The program is designed to give students a comprehensive understanding of the craft of writing for television, from sitcoms to hour-long dramas, with an emphasis on creating compelling characters, developing engaging storylines, and mastering the formatting and structural conventions of the industry. Through a combination of workshops, lectures, and hands-on writing assignments, students will develop a portfolio of work that demonstrates their ability to craft high-quality television scripts. The program also offers opportunities for students to connect with industry professionals, gain practical experience, and explore potential career paths in television writing.

The Minor in Theatre Arts is designed to give students an opportunity to experience various aspects of the art and discipline of theatre while complementing their major course of study. The minor requires a total of 21 credits. Students must complete one course from each of the following four areas: Theatre History and Literature, Performance, Design and Technology, and Dramatic Theory. In addition, students must complete three credits of a capstone experience and three credits of theatre electives. The remaining six credits may be taken in any theatre area. A minimum grade of C must be achieved in all courses for the minor. Students interested in auditioning or interviewing for departmental productions are encouraged to contact the Theatre Arts Program for information regarding opportunities. It is also recommended that students meet with the undergraduate director to discuss specific courses appropriate for their goals. For more information regarding the program, please contact the Theatre Arts Program at (631) 632-7330.

The minor in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies (WGS) provides students with an interdisciplinary understanding of the social and cultural construction of gender, the historical and contemporary status of women, and the importance of sexuality in human experience. The minor is a useful complement to a wide array of majors across the humanities, social sciences, sciences, and professional schools. The minor encourages students to analyze the social world, understand power relations, and engage in social change. It provides students with critical thinking, writing, and communication skills applicable to any career, as well as an understanding of diversity and intersectionality essential for global citizenship.
Program name: Minor in Women's and Gender Studies

description: A minor in Writing and Rhetoric provides students with the opportunity to refine their analytical and rhetorical skills as readers and writers. Through the study of a range of texts, contexts, and genres, students cultivate an understanding of writing as a social and intellectual activity in academic, professional, and civic life. The minor offers students the opportunity to choose from courses focusing on topics such as rhetoric and composition theory, digital rhetoric, professional writing, writing for social change, and the teaching of writing.
